questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about mechanical waves?

options.A: They can travel without a medium.
options.B: They require a medium to propagate.
options.C: They do not involve oscillations of particles.
options.D: They are examples of electromagnetic waves.

questions.hint: Think about why sound cannot travel through a vacuum.
questions.explanation: Mechanical waves need a material medium (like air, water, or a string) to travel. This is a key characteristic that distinguishes them from electromagnetic waves.
questions.solution: Mechanical waves require a medium to propagate, so the correct answer is B.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a mechanical wave?
questions.hint: Mechanical waves involve vibrating particles of a medium.
questions.explanation: Waves in a string require the presence of the material (string) for transmission, demonstrating mechanical wave behavior.
questions.solution: Waves in a string are mechanical waves, so option C is correct.

questions.question_text: In a transverse wave, how does the motion of the particle compare to the direction of propagation of the wave?

options.A: It is in the same direction as the wave.
options.B: It is in the opposite direction of the wave.
options.C: It is perpendicular to the direction of the wave.

questions.hint: Recall how a string moves when you make a wave in it.
questions.explanation: In transverse waves, such as those in a string, particles move up and down while the wave itself travels horizontally—these motions are perpendicular.
questions.solution: The motion of the particle is perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation, so C is correct.

questions.question_text: What happens in a longitudinal wave as it propagates through a medium?

options.A: Particles of the medium move in circular paths.
options.D: A vacuum is needed for transmission.

questions.hint: Listen carefully to descriptions of sound waves in a spring.
questions.explanation: Longitudinal waves are characterized by alternate regions of compression and rarefaction moving through the medium.
questions.solution: Option C is correct: compressions and rarefactions are formed in longitudinal waves.

questions.question_text: Which of the following waves can travel through a vacuum?
questions.hint: This type of wave includes light from the sun.
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves, such as light, do not need any material medium to travel and can propagate through a vacuum.
questions.solution: Electromagnetic waves travel through vacuum, so C is correct.

questions.question_text: What is the main difference between the study of oscillations and wave motion as described in the lecture?

options.A: Oscillations involve waves; wave motion involves only particles.
options.B: Oscillations involve single particle motion; wave motion involves a group of particles.
options.C: Both focus only on one particle at a time.

questions.hint: Think about the number of particles considered in each type of motion.
questions.explanation: Oscillations study the movement of a single particle, while wave motion concerns the behavior of a set or system of particles interacting.
questions.solution: Wave motion deals with a group/system of particles; so B is correct.

questions.question_text: Select the correct statement about electromagnetic waves based on the summary.

options.B: They require a string as a medium.
options.D: They are a type of mechanical wave.

questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves are distinct from mechanical waves because they do not require any medium and can travel through the vacuum of space.
questions.solution: Option C correctly states that electromagnetic waves can travel through a vacuum.

questions.question_text: If a particle moves up and down while the wave spreads horizontally along a string, what type of wave is being described?
questions.hint: Think about the motion of the medium’s particles relative to wave direction.
questions.explanation: Transverse waves involve particle motion perpendicular to the propagation direction, as in a string.
questions.solution: This describes a mechanical wave that is transverse, so option B is correct.
